title: R43770
content: The hidden feature of federal crimes is that helpers and offenders face the same punishment under 18 U.S.C. 2, which holds anyone who orders a federal crime accountable. This secondary liability is similar to conspiracy, as society fears the crimes of multiple individuals. The aiding and abetting subsection is more commonly prosecuted than the causes subsection. Society fears crimes committed by multiple individuals more than those committed by one person. Aiding and abetting in federal crimes holds individuals accountable as principals, with the aiding and abetting subsection being more frequently prosecuted than the causes subsection. To aid and abet a crime, a defendant must associate themselves with the venture, participate in it, and seek to make it succeed. To aid and abet a crime, a defendant must associate themselves with the venture, participate in it, and consciously contribute to its success by knowing the offense is happening before it occurs. Aiding and abetting involves assisting in someone else's crime by embracing the crime, consciously contributing to its success, and knowing the offense is happening before it occurs. The defendant does not need to aid in every aspect of the crime, and even minimal assistance can make them liable as a principal. At common law, aiding and abetting required the defendant to assist in the substantive offense, with even minimal aid making them liable.
